   Summary of the entire C program:

        #include <stdio.h>
        #include <stdlib.h>
        #include <string.h>

        #define TABLE_SIZE 10007

        // For the set (for the first program) we define a linked list node.
        struct node {
            long long val;
            struct node *next;
        };

        struct node *set[TABLE_SIZE] = {NULL};   // global? or we can make it local and initialize to NULL.

        // Hash function: 
        unsigned int hash(long long x) {
            unsigned int value = (unsigned int)(x % TABLE_SIZE);
            return value % TABLE_SIZE;
        }

        // Insert into the set: returns 1 if inserted (i.e., it was not present), 0 if duplicate.
        int insert_set(long long x) {
            unsigned int idx = hash(x);
            struct node *p = set[idx];
            while (p != NULL) {
                if (p->val == x) {
                    return 0;   // already present
                }
                p = p->next;
            }
            // not found -> insert at head
            struct node *new_node = (struct node*)malloc(sizeof(struct node));
            new_node->val = x;
            new_node->next = set[idx];
            set[idx] = new_node;
            return 1;
        }

        int contains(long long x) {
            unsigned int idx = hash(x);
            struct node *p = set[idx];
            while (p != NULL) {
                if (p->val == x) {
                    return 1;
                }
                p = p->next;
            }
            return 0;
        }

        // Function to free the set? Not necessary for this program.

        // Compare function for qsort
        int compare(const void *a, const void *b) {
            long long va = *(long long*)a;
            long long vb = *(long long*)b;
            if (va < vb) return -1;
            if (va > vb) return 1;
            return 0;
        }

        // Function for floor division: 
        long long floor_div(long long x, long long k) {
            if (x >= 0) {
                return x / k;
            } else {
                return (x - (k-1)) / k;
            }
        }

        int main() {
            int num, k;
            scanf("%d %d", &num, &k);
            long long *arr = (long long*)malloc(num * sizeof(long long));
            for (int i=0; i<num; i++) {
                scanf("%lld", &arr[i]);
            }

            // Sort the array
            qsort(arr, num, sizeof(long long), compare);

            // Initialize set (global) to NULL? 
            for (int i=0; i<TABLE_SIZE; i++) {
                set[i] = NULL;
            }

            int set_size = 0;
            int temp = 0;   // the maximum set size during traversal

            for (int i=0; i<num; i++) {
                long long x = arr[i];
                long long q = floor_div(x, k);

                // Check condition
                // Note: in C, modulus for negative: we adjust to nonnegative? 
                // We want: x % k in a way that is nonnegative? 
                // Because the condition: if (x % k != 0) 
                // But in Python, modulus for negative is nonnegative? 
                // We can compute modulus as: 
                //   long long mod = x % k;
                //   if (mod < 0) mod += k;
                long long mod = x % k;
                if (mod < 0) mod += k;

                if (mod != 0 || !contains(q)) {
                    // Then we try to insert x (if not already present)
                    int inserted = insert_set(x);
                    if (inserted) {
                        set_size++;
                    }
                }
                // Update temp: the maximum set_size so far
                if (set_size > temp) {
                    temp = set_size;
                }
            }

            free(arr);

            // Now convert temp to a string
            char str[20];   // enough for an integer (up to 10 digits)
            sprintf(str, "%d", temp);

            // Now the second program: process the string `str`
            int freq[256] = {0};   // frequency array for ASCII
            int len = strlen(str);
            for (int i=0; i<len; i++) {
                unsigned char c = str[i];
                freq[c]++;
            }

            // Count distinct characters
            int distinct_count = 0;
            for (int i=0; i<256; i++) {
                if (freq[i] > 0) {
                    distinct_count++;
                }
            }

            if (distinct_count != 2) {
                printf("No\n");
            } else {
                int valid = 1;
                for (int i=0; i<256; i++) {
                    if (freq[i] != 0 && freq[i] != 2) {
                        valid = 0;
                        break;
                    }
                }
                if (valid) {
                    printf("Yes\n");
                } else {
                    printf("No\n");
                }
            }

            // Free the set? 
            for (int i=0; i<TABLE_SIZE; i++) {
                struct node *p = set[i];
                while (p != NULL) {
                    struct node *tmp = p;
                    p = p->next;
                    free(tmp);
                }
            }

            return 0;
        }

   But note: the condition in the first program uses `x % k != 0`. In our C code, we adjusted the modulus to be nonnegative? 

        In Python: 
            x % k is nonnegative? 
            So we adjust: if the modulus is negative, we add k to get in the range [0, k-1].

        Then we compare: mod != 0.

        This matches the Python condition.

   Let me test with negative x and positive k: 
        x = -3, k=2: 
            In C: 
                mod = (-3) % 2 -> in C: this is -1? 
                then we adjust: mod = -1 + 2 = 1 -> then condition: 1 != 0 -> true.

        In Python:
